div.p: ANTONIO: Earlier we talked about how we don't make diet and exercise choices in a vacuum. And as you might guess, it's not any different when it comes to alcohol and drugs.
ANTONIO: Anyone who makes high-risk choices can develop alcoholism or drug addiction. But, not everyone is as likely to make high-risk choices.
ANTONIO: Michelle Ellison from PRI is back to talk about the two major categories of things that influence our choices—psychological factors and social factors.
ANTONIO: Michelle, thanks for joining us again.
MICHELLE: Hey, good to be back Antonio.
ANTONIO: So let's start first with psychological factors.
MICHELLE: You know, right out of the blocks are psychological influences are an important part of who we are—they are things like our values, beliefs and personality.
ANTONIO: Right, we talked about this earlier in relation to heart disease. If I believe that exercising is a waste of time, that's going to influence the choices I make.
MICHELLE: Right. When it comes to the psychological factors that could influence high-risk choices, most of us think about things like stress, emotional problems, or maybe low-self esteem.
ANTONIO: I've also heard about "an addictive personality."
MICHELLE: For the most part, no. But there's just enough truth in there that it's misleading.
MICHELLE: Well, some people do drink or use drugs as a result of emotional problems. But the bigger question is—is it typical?
ANTONIO: That's a good question. We're going to explore it further.
